title: COMP/STAT112 Notebook
text:
Welcome
Welcome to my online portfolio for COMP/STAT112 course taken at Macalester College. Please, use the side bar on the left for navigation.

title: 1  Univariate Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking univariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

# Import data
hikes <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/high_peaks.csv")
head(hikes)

             peak elevation difficulty ascent length time    rating
1     Mt. Marcy        5344          5   3166   14.8 10.0  moderate
2 Algonquin Peak       5114          5   2936    9.6  9.0  moderate
3   Mt. Haystack       4960          7   3570   17.8 12.0 difficult
4   Mt. Skylight       4926          7   4265   17.9 15.0 difficult
5 Whiteface Mtn.       4867          4   2535   10.4  8.5      easy
6       Dix Mtn.       4857          5   2800   13.2 10.0  moderate

# Use the ggplot function


# Load the package
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)

#| fig-cap: "Distribution of hikes across different elevations"
#| fig-alt: "Histogram chart that shows hikes across different elevation breakpoints, most hikes lie within 4,000-5,000ft "
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "blue",fill = "green", binwidth = 200) +
  labs(x = "Elevation (ft)", y = "Number of hikes", title = "Number of Hikes by Elevation")

title: 2  Bivariate Viz
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)


# Import and check out data
education <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/sat.csv")
head(education)

       State expend ratio salary frac verbal math  sat  fracCat
1    Alabama  4.405  17.2 31.144    8    491  538 1029   (0,15]
2     Alaska  8.963  17.6 47.951   47    445  489  934 (45,100]
3    Arizona  4.778  19.3 32.175   27    448  496  944  (15,45]
4   Arkansas  4.459  17.1 28.934    6    482  523 1005   (0,15]
5 California  4.992  24.0 41.078   45    417  485  902  (15,45]
6   Colorado  5.443  18.4 34.571   29    462  518  980  (15,45]



ggplot(education,aes(x=sat,fill=fracCat)) +
  geom_density(alpha=0.5) +labs (x= "Average S.A.T Score", y= "Density", title = "How does Participation Rate Effect Average SAT Scores Across School Districts?")



Average SAT scores based on low, medium and high participation rate



Use this file to generate a professional looking bivariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

title: 3  Trivariate Viz
text:
library("ggplot2")
elections <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")
#| fig-cap: "Rebublican support in 2020 by Counties related to support in 2016"
#| fig-alt: "A scatter plot showing  Republican support in 2016 on the X and 2020 support on Y with a red best fit line showing a strong positive corolation between the two the dots are colored based on the historical political leaning of the county showing historical trends were not interupted by either election cycle"

ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16,color= historical)) + scale_color_manual(values = c("blue","purple","red"))+
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4) +labs(x="Republican Percent Vote in 2016", y= "Republican Percent Vote in 2020", title = "Did Republican Support in 2016 Carry Over into 2020?")+
  geom_smooth(color = "black")

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'








Use this file to generate a professional looking trivariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

title: 4  Quadvariate Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking quadvariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

weather <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/weather_3_locations.csv") |> 
  mutate(date = as.Date(date))  


#| fig-cap: "Faceted by Location, Colored by Rain Outcome"
#| fig-alt: "Scatterplot depicting Tempature at 9am and 3Pm at 3 different locations colored based on if it rained that day. In general,Uluru is the hottest and 3pm tempature corolates with 9pm tempature regardless of if it rained or not."
ggplot(weather, aes(y = temp3pm, x = temp9am, colour = raintoday)) + 
  
  geom_point(alpha=0.3)+facet_wrap(~location)+ geom_smooth()+labs(title = "Can the Tempature at 9AM Predict the Tempature at 3PM?", y ="Tempature at 3PM",x ="Tempature at 9PM"  )

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'

(`stat_smooth()`).

title: 5  Spatial Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking spatial visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

elections_by_state <-  read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_by_state.csv")
elections_by_counties <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")

library(leaflet)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dplyr)
library(mosaic)

Registered S3 method overwritten by 'mosaic':
  method                           from   
  fortify.SpatialPolygonsDataFrame ggplot2

The 'mosaic' package masks several functions from core packages in order to add 
additional features.  The original behavior of these functions should not be affected by this.

Attaching package: 'mosaic'

The following object is masked from 'package:Matrix':

    mean

The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr':

    count, do, tally

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    cross

The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    stat

The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    binom.test, cor, cor.test, cov, fivenum, IQR, median, prop.test,
    quantile, sd, t.test, var

The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    max, mean, min, prod, range, sample, sum

library(rnaturalearth)
library(gplots)


Attaching package: 'gplots'

The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    lowess

elections_by_state <- elections_by_state |> 
  filter(state_abbr != "DC") |> 
  select(state_name, state_abbr, repub_pct_20) |> 
  mutate(repub_20_categories = 
           cut(repub_pct_20, 
               breaks = seq(30, 70, by = 5), 
               labels = c("30-34", "35-39", "40-44", "45-49",
                          "50-54", "55-59", "60-64", "65-70"), 
               include.lowest = TRUE))

elections_by_counties <- elections_by_counties |> 
  select(state_name, state_abbr, county_name, county_fips,
          repub_pct_20, median_age, median_rent) |> 
  mutate(repub_20_categories = 
           cut(repub_pct_20, 
               breaks = seq(0, 100, by = 10),
               labels = c("0-9", "10-19", "20-29", "30-39", "40-49",
                          "50-59", "60-69", "70-79", "80-89", "90-100"),
               include.lowest = TRUE))
states_map <- map_data("state")


library(RColorBrewer)
#| fig-cap: "States shaded by % of Republican voters"
#| fig-alt: "Chloropleth Map colored by % of Republican Voters lower % are shaded blue and higher $ are shaded red, most red states are  N.Dakota, Oaklahoma and Colorodo likely also due to their lower populations"
ggplot(elections_by_state, aes(map_id = state_name, fill = repub_20_categories)) +
  geom_map(map = states_map) +
  expand_limits(x = states_map$long, y = states_map$lat) +labs(title = "Percentage of Republican Voters by State")+ 
  theme_map() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = rev(brewer.pal(8, "RdBu")), name = "% Republican")

title: 6  ICA 3
text:
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
geom_bar(color = “orange”, fill = “blue”) +
labs(x = “Rating”, y = “Number of hikes”) +
theme_minimal()
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation))

# Import data
hikes <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/high_peaks.csv")
head(hikes)

             peak elevation difficulty ascent length time    rating
1     Mt. Marcy        5344          5   3166   14.8 10.0  moderate
2 Algonquin Peak       5114          5   2936    9.6  9.0  moderate
3   Mt. Haystack       4960          7   3570   17.8 12.0 difficult
4   Mt. Skylight       4926          7   4265   17.9 15.0 difficult
5 Whiteface Mtn.       4867          4   2535   10.4  8.5      easy
6       Dix Mtn.       4857          5   2800   13.2 10.0  moderate

# Use the ggplot function


# Load the package
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating))






# you added geombar which adds bars to the chart
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar()






# adds y axis and labels 
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")






# adds fill making bars blue
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")






# makes an orenge outline on the bars (very mac coded)
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(color = "orange", fill = "blue") +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes")






# theme  minimal, the bar disapear
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = rating)) +
  geom_bar(color = "orange", fill = "blue")  +
  labs(x = "Rating", y = "Number of hikes") +
  theme_minimal()






# makes a grey bar chart showing amount of hikes at different elevations
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.







# adds a white outline??
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white") 

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.







# makes the bars blue with a white outline
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "blue") 

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.







# makes the bars thinner and cover smaller ranges of elevation
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white") +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.







# makes the bars wider and cover higher ranges of elevation
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 1000) +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")






# Happy medium? ideal graph? no title though
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 200) +
  labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")






#makes a line density chart by elevation
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
  geom_density()






ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) + 
  geom_density(color = "red", fill = "white") + 
  labs(x = "elevation(feet)", y = "density")






# YUCK
ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) +
geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 200) +
labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")






ggplot(hikes, aes(x = elevation)) + geom_histogram(color = "white", binwidth = 200) + labs(x = "Elevation (feet)", y = "Number of hikes")






# Data on students in this class
survey <- read.csv("https://hash-mac.github.io/stat112site-s25/data/survey.csv")

# World Cup data
world_cup <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2022/2022-11-29/worldcups.csv")

ggplot(world_cup, aes(x = year))+
  geom_histogram() + 
  labs(x = "year", y = "goals scored") 

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: 7  Bivariate Viz
text:
Use this file for practice with the bivariate viz in-class activity. Refer to the class website for details.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1

✔ purrr     1.0.2

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)
# Load data
elections <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")

# Check it out
head(elections)

  state_name state_abbr historical    county_name county_fips total_votes_20

5    Alabama         AL        red  Blount County        1009          27588
6    Alabama         AL        red Bullock County        1011           4613
  repub_pct_20 dem_pct_20 winner_20 total_votes_16 repub_pct_16 dem_pct_16
1        71.44      27.02     repub          24661        73.44      23.96
2        76.17      22.41     repub          94090        77.35      19.57
3        53.45      45.79     repub          10390        52.27      46.66

  winner_16 total_votes_12 repub_pct_12 dem_pct_12 winner_12 total_population
1     repub          23909        72.63      26.58     repub            54907
2     repub          84988        77.39      21.57     repub           187114
3     repub          11459        48.34      51.25       dem            27321

  percent_white percent_black percent_asian percent_hispanic per_capita_income
1            76            18             1                2             24571

  median_rent median_age
1         668       37.5

ggplot(elections, aes(x=repub_pct_16, y=repub_pct_20))+ geom_point()






# directly corolated repub support in 2016 is a good indicator for support in 2020, some drifting points imply growin support from 2016-2020


ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'gam' and formula = 'y ~ s(x, bs = "cs")'









ggplot(elections, aes(y = repub_pct_20, x = repub_pct_16)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: 8  ICA5 put in right place later
text:
8.1 R Markdown
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:
summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
crumbs: 8  ICA5 put in right place later

title: 8  ICA5 put in right place later
text:
8.2 Including Plots
You can also embed plots, for example:








Note that the echo = FALSE parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
crumbs: 8  ICA5 put in right place later

title: 9  Spatial Viz
text:
Use this file for practice with the spatial viz in-class activity. Refer to the class website for details.

fave_places <- read.csv("https://hash-mac.github.io/stat112site-s25/data/our_fave_places.csv")

# Check it out
head(fave_places)

  latitude longitude
1       59        18
2       45       -93
3       33      -117
4       40       116
5       40       106
6       37      -122



# Load the leaflet package
library(leaflet)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dplyr)
library(mosaic)

Registered S3 method overwritten by 'mosaic':
  method                           from   
  fortify.SpatialPolygonsDataFrame ggplot2

The 'mosaic' package masks several functions from core packages in order to add 
additional features.  The original behavior of these functions should not be affected by this.

Attaching package: 'mosaic'

The following object is masked from 'package:Matrix':

    mean

The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr':

    count, do, tally

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    cross

The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    stat

The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    binom.test, cor, cor.test, cov, fivenum, IQR, median, prop.test,
    quantile, sd, t.test, var

The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    max, mean, min, prod, range, sample, sum

library(rnaturalearth)
library(gplots)


Attaching package: 'gplots'

The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    lowess

# Just a plotting frame
leaflet(data = fave_places)






# Now what do we have?
leaflet(data = fave_places) |> 
  addTiles()






# Now what do we have?
# longitude and latitude refer to the variables in our data
leaflet(data = fave_places) |> 
  addTiles() |> 
  addMarkers(lng = ~longitude, lat = ~latitude)






# Since we named them "longitude" and "latitude", the function
# automatically recognizes these variables. No need to write them!
leaflet(data = fave_places) |> 
  addTiles() |> 
  addMarkers()






# Load package needed to change color
library(gplots)

# We can add colored circles instead of markers at each location
leaflet(data = fave_places) |> 
  addTiles() |> 
  addCircles(color = col2hex("red"))






# We can change the background
# Mark locations with yellow dots
# And connect the dots, in their order in the dataset, with green lines
# (These green lines don't mean anything here, but would if this were somebody's travel path!)
leaflet(data = fave_places) |>
  addProviderTiles("USGS") |>
  addCircles(weight = 10, opacity = 1, color = col2hex("yellow")) |>
  addPolylines(
    lng = ~longitude,
    lat = ~latitude,
    color = col2hex("green")
  )




#I don't know where the orginal file went for this, I promise I did all of this in class


elections_by_state <-  read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_by_state.csv")
elections_by_counties <- read.csv("https://mac-stat.github.io/data/election_2020_county.csv")
# Don't worry about the code!

elections_by_state <- elections_by_state |> 
  filter(state_abbr != "DC") |> 
  select(state_name, state_abbr, repub_pct_20) |> 
  mutate(repub_20_categories = 
           cut(repub_pct_20, 
               breaks = seq(30, 70, by = 5), 
               labels = c("30-34", "35-39", "40-44", "45-49",
                          "50-54", "55-59", "60-64", "65-70"), 
               include.lowest = TRUE))

elections_by_counties <- elections_by_counties |> 
  select(state_name, state_abbr, county_name, county_fips,
          repub_pct_20, median_age, median_rent) |> 
  mutate(repub_20_categories = 
           cut(repub_pct_20, 
               breaks = seq(0, 100, by = 10),
               labels = c("0-9", "10-19", "20-29", "30-39", "40-49",
                          "50-59", "60-69", "70-79", "80-89", "90-100"),
               include.lowest = TRUE))
# Get the latitude and longitude coordinates of state boundaries
states_map <- map_data("state")

# Check it out
head(states_map)

       long      lat group order  region subregion
1 -87.46201 30.38968     1     1 alabama      <NA>
2 -87.48493 30.37249     1     2 alabama      <NA>
3 -87.52503 30.37249     1     3 alabama      <NA>
4 -87.53076 30.33239     1     4 alabama      <NA>
5 -87.57087 30.32665     1     5 alabama      <NA>
6 -87.58806 30.32665     1     6 alabama      <NA>

# Note where the dataset, elections_by_state, is used
# Note where the background map, states_map, is used
ggplot(elections_by_state, aes(map_id = state_name, fill = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_map(map = states_map) +
  expand_limits(x = states_map$long, y = states_map$lat) +
  theme_map() 






# Make it nicer!
ggplot(elections_by_state, aes(map_id = state_name, fill = repub_pct_20)) +
  geom_map(map = states_map) +
  expand_limits(x = states_map$long, y = states_map$lat) +
  theme_map() + 
  scale_fill_gradientn(name = "% Republican", colors = c("blue", "purple", "red"), values = scales::rescale(seq(0, 100, by = 5)))








# Load package needed for refining color palette
library(RColorBrewer)

# Now fix the colors
ggplot(elections_by_state, aes(map_id = state_name, fill = repub_20_categories)) +
  geom_map(map = states_map) +
  expand_limits(x = states_map$long, y = states_map$lat) +
  theme_map() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = rev(brewer.pal(8, "RdBu")), name = "% Republican")
